intro: Nolana tarapacana, commonly known as the "Cordillera flower" or "Puya," is a flowering plant native to the Atacama Desert in Chile. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its striking, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant is adapted to extreme arid conditions, with a deep root system and waxy leaves that minimize water loss. It blooms during the rainy season, typically between November and March, and is often found growing in rocky soils. Nolana tarapacana is also known for its medicinal properties and has been used in traditional Andean medicine.
